name: Pushkar
fun_fact: Fun fact: Pushkar is one of the few places in the world where eating meat and eggs is COMPLETELY FORBIDDEN - the entire town is holy because it's the only place on Earth with a temple dedicated to Lord Brahma (the creator god), and even alcohol is banned!

hero_dishes.name: Dal Baati Churma
hero_dishes.description: Hard wheat balls (baati) with lentils (dal) and sweet crumbled wheat (churma)
hero_dishes.origin_story: The quintessential Rajasthani meal - baati are baked in desert sand traditionally. Served with lashings of ghee
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Om Shiva Garden Restaurant, Sixth Sense, traditional Rajasthani restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Malpua
hero_dishes.description: Sweet fried pancakes soaked in sugar syrup, often topped with rabri (reduced milk)
hero_dishes.origin_story: A specialty of Pushkar - these sweet treats are especially popular during religious festivals
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Pushkar Bazaar sweet shops, Halwairam, temple area vendors

hero_dishes.name: Kachori
hero_dishes.description: Deep-fried puffed pastry filled with spiced lentils or peas
hero_dishes.origin_story: The perfect vegetarian snack - Rajasthan's answer to the samosa
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors around Pushkar Lake, Halwairam sweet shop

hero_dishes.name: Poha
hero_dishes.description: Flattened rice cooked with onions, peas, and spices - common breakfast
hero_dishes.origin_story: A light, healthy breakfast found throughout India but perfected in Rajasthan

signature_drinks.name: Lassi
signature_drinks.description: Thick yogurt drink, sweet or salted, sometimes with rose or saffron
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Essential for cooling down - makhaniya lassi (with cream) is Rajasthani specialty

signature_drinks.name: Masala Chai
signature_drinks.description: Spiced tea with milk, cardamom, ginger, and other spices
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Constantly throughout the day from chai wallahs around the lake

food_culture_notes: STRICTLY VEGETARIAN - no meat, fish, or eggs allowed anywhere in town
No alcohol - Pushkar is a holy city
Pushkar Camel Fair (November) brings food stalls from across Rajasthan
Many rooftop restaurants overlook the sacred lake
